title: 107_s930
content:
The "Grand Canyon Capital Improvements Act of 2001" includes sections on short title, definitions, fundraising organization, memorandum of agreement, park surcharge, use of bond proceeds, report, and regulations. SEC. 2. DEFINITIONS.

Fundraising organization - entity authorized under section 3(a).
Memorandum of agreement - agreement with terms specified in section 4.
Park - Grand Canyon National Park.
Secretary - Secretary of the Interior.

SEC. 3. FUNDRAISING ORGANIZATION. SEC. 3. FUNDRAISING ORGANIZATION.

The Secretary may enter into a memorandum of agreement with an entity to act as an authorized fundraising organization for the benefit of the Park. The fundraising organization shall issue taxable bonds in return for the surcharge collected for the Park. It must comply with professional standards and be subject to an audit. The United States is not liable for any bonds issued by the fundraising organization. SEC. 4. MEMORANDUM OF AGREEMENT specifies bond details, maturity not exceeding 20 years, per capita amount for bond repayment and administration costs, project funding at the Park, and modification procedures. The Secretary may authorize the Superintendent of the Park to charge a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under various acts. The Secretary may authorize a surcharge of up to $2 per individual in addition to entrance fees collected under various acts. The surcharge must not exceed $2 per individual and must be used for bond amortization, administration costs, and maintaining a reserve. SEC. 6. USE OF BOND PROCEEDS. Bond proceeds under this Act can be used for projects in the Park, subject to certain limitations and prohibitions. Projects must align with laws governing the National Park System, Park laws, and the Park's general management plan. Administrative expenses cannot be covered by bond proceeds, except for interest. Interest earned can be used to meet reserve requirements. The bond proceeds can be used to meet reserve requirements and cover administrative expenses related to managing and selling the bonds. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of regulations being issued, reviewing the bond program at the Park and providing recommendations on establishing a bond program at all National Park units. The Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Treasury, will promulgate regulations to implement the Act.
